passages.text: We've had a hundred years of psychotherapy and the world's getting worse.
passages.source: We've Had a Hundred Years of Psychotherapy
passages.context: The provocative opening. Individual therapy hasn't healed the world. Something's missing.

passages.text: The soul doesn't want to be saved; it wants to be deepened.
passages.context: Soul isn't asking for rescue — it's asking for depth. Salvation misunderstands what soul needs.

passages.text: It is more important to know what sort of person has a disease than to know what sort of disease a person has.
passages.context: Person before diagnosis. Who has this symptom matters more than what the symptom is.

passages.text: We are not what we think we are. We are the myths that think us.
passages.context: Myths aren't stories we tell — they're patterns that live through us. We don't have myths; myths have us.

passages.text: The acorn theory proposes that each person bears a uniqueness that asks to be lived and that is already present before it can be lived.
passages.context: You came with a code, a calling, a daimon. Life is the unpacking of what was always there.

passages.text: Depression opens the door to beauty of some kind.
passages.context: Depression isn't only pathology — it's soul making room. Something beautiful may be trying to enter.

passages.text: We need to get off the therapeutic couch and out into the streets, to make our protest against the madness of public life.
passages.source: We've Had a Hundred Years of Psychotherapy
passages.context: Psychology needs to leave the consulting room. The world's pathology requires political response.

passages.text: Pathologizing is the psyche's autonomous ability to create illness, morbidity, disorder, abnormality, and suffering in any aspect of its behavior.
passages.context: Symptoms aren't accidents — the psyche creates them on purpose. Pathology has intention.

passages.text: The psychological rule says that when an inner situation is not made conscious, it happens outside as fate.
passages.context: What you don't face inside, you meet outside. Unconscious content becomes external event.

passages.text: It's a myth to think we can be psychological without being theological, that we can examine the soul without examining the Gods.
passages.context: Psychology can't escape religion. To study soul is to encounter the divine, whether you name it or not.

passages.text: The word 'normal' in our society means something average, and 'abnormal' means something morbid. But from the point of view of soul, 'normal' is morbid.
passages.context: Statistical normality isn't soul health. What's common may be deeply sick from soul's perspective.

passages.text: Imagination is the primary activity of the soul, and imagining is not merely decorative or escapist, but reality itself.
passages.context: Imagination isn't ornament — it's foundational. The imaginal is as real as the literal.

passages.text: The way through the world is more difficult to find than the way beyond it.
passages.context: It's easier to escape the world than to navigate it. Engagement is harder than transcendence.

passages.text: Every symptom is a living process, a way of being, trying to tell us something.
passages.context: Symptoms have intention — they're communications. Listen before you suppress.

passages.text: Children today are medicated and diagnosed in place of being mythologized. We give them Ritalin rather than a story.
passages.context: We drug what we could narrate. Children need stories about who they are, not pills to change them.

passages.text: That I am alive is a gift. That I live the life I live — that's something else.
passages.context: Existence is grace. But what we do with existence — that's on us.

passages.text: When the sense of calling is lost, we have entered the dark night of the soul.
passages.context: The dark night isn't depression — it's losing your sense of purpose. Calling connects us to meaning.

passages.text: Psychology is ultimately mythology, the study of the stories of the soul.
passages.context: Psychology and mythology are the same discipline. The soul lives in stories.

passages.text: Soul-making requires the experiencing of a problem as its own answer.
passages.context: The problem IS the path. Soul-making doesn't eliminate problems — it transforms relationship to them.

passages.text: Follow the accident, find the soul. Where you stumble, there lies your treasure.
passages.context: Mistakes aren't errors — they're signposts. What trips you up may be pointing toward your gold.
